channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ally, Member or Partner? NATO’s Long Dilemma Over Ukraine.
item.description: NATO promised Ukraine full membership in 2008, but without explaining how or when. Putin sees that promise as an ongoing threat to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg addresses the NATO foreign ministers’ meeting in Riga in November, where ministers discussed how to counter the Russian military build-up on the Ukrainian border.

item.title: With Olaf Scholz at the Helm in Germany, a New, Uncertain Chapter
item.description: After 16 years, Angela Merkel handed over the German chancellery to Olaf Scholz, leaving behind a changed country and a polarizing legacy.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz, right, and former Chancellor Angela Merkel at the Chancellery on Wednesday.

item.title: Upik Lawanga, Indonesian Militant, Is Sentenced to Life in Prison
item.description: A court said Upik Lawanga made bombs for an attack that killed 22 people at a market. He is a member of a terrorist group that bombed churches, hotels and a Bali nightclub in the 2000s.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Police officers escorting the Islamic militant Upik Lawanga in Tangerang, Indonesia, in December 2020.

item.title: India’s Top Military General, Bipin Rawat, Dies in Helicopter Crash
item.description: Gen. Bipin Rawat, who was killed along with his wife and 11 others on board, was in charge of overhauling a military that has struggled to modernize.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Firemen and rescue workers at the site of the helicopter crash in Coonoor, Tamil Nadu, that killed Gen. Bipin Rawat on Wednesday.

item.title: Jailed Journalists Reach Record High for Sixth Year in 2021
item.description: The Committee to Protect Journalists, a press freedom monitoring group, said 293 journalists were behind bars this year, more than a quarter of them in China.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: Jimmy Lai, the Hong Kong media tycoon and founder of Apple Daily, being arrested in 2020. He is the highest profile journalist of 50 imprisoned by China.

item.title: Coronavirus Cases Are Rising Among Children in South African Hospitals
item.description: The increase, observed in children’s wards at two major hospitals in South Africa, points to increased community transmission, doctors say.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: A boy receiving a coronavirus vaccine near Johannesburg on Wednesday.

item.title: Defector Helps Build Case Against Belarus Over Ryanair Flight It Forced Down
item.description: A former air traffic controller has been telling Polish investigators what he knows about the diversion of the plane carrying a Belarus dissident in May.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Tomas Dapkus
item.media:description: A Ryanair aircraft landing in Vilnius, Lithuania, on May 23. The plane had previously been forced to land in Minsk, Belarus, where two passengers, including the opposition activist Roman Protasevich, were arrested.

item.title: Wrong Man Arrested Over Khashoggi Killing, France Says
item.description: The French authorities released a Saudi man who shared the name and age of a suspect in the murder of the dissident writer, saying it was a case of mistaken identity.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Friends of the Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi displayed posters bearing his image outside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul last year, to mark the second anniversary of his killing.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Boosters against the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vaccinations in Hemmingen, Germany.

item.title: Pfizer Says Its Booster Is Effective Against Omicron
item.description: The company’s finding is based on only a small study of blood samples in a laboratory, but others are sure to follow.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pfizer-BioNTech’s small study of blood samples in a laboratory is not proof of how the vaccines will perform in the real world.

item.title: U.S. Threat to Squeeze Russia’s Economy Is a Tactic With a Mixed Record
item.description: Sanctions, like aiming to cut oil exports, could also hurt European allies. “It’s a limited toolbox,” one expert said.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.category: SWIFT(Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication)
item.media:description: A drilling rig in the Yarakta oilfield in Russia. Outside of the oil industry, Russia’s international trade and investments are limited.

item.title: The World Is Unprepared for the Next Pandemic, Report Says
item.description: The latest Global Health Security Index finds that no country is positioned well to respond to outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:description: Emergency technicians removed a patient bed from an overflow tent at a hospital in California this year.

item.title: The Coronavirus Attacks Fat Tissue, Scientists Find
item.description: The research may help explain why people who are overweight and obese have been at higher risk of severe illness and death from Covid.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: Research has found that the coronavirus infects fat cells and immune cells within body fat, causing an immune response that scientists say may contribute to severe disease.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Pfizer’s Booster and Omicron.
item.description: The booster protects, and two shots may not be enough.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Matthew Busch for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nurse draws the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine into a syringe during a vaccination clinic in San Antonio, Texas, in September.

item.title: Justo Gallego, Who Built a Cathedral, Brick by Brick, Dies at 96
item.description: A former monk, he spent decades constructing a grand edifice as an act of faith and devotion, and did so almost single-handedly.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:credit: Gianfranco Tripodo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justo Gallego at his cathedral in the Spanish town of Mejorada del Campo in 2017. “I’ve not been building this to get money or fame,” he said, “just as I’m not here to listen to people decide whether I’m mad or unique.”

item.title: Proposal Would Allow E.U. to Retaliate Against Economic Pressure
item.description: The European Commission is considering sweeping powers to impose punitive sanctions on those seeking to influence its political policies through economic pressure.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Valdis Dombrovskis, the European Union’s commissioner for trade, middle, right, at a G7 trade summit in London in October.

item.title: Britain Introduces 'Plan B' Covid Measures to Tackle Omicron
item.description: People in England will be urged to work from home and have to show proof of vaccination. Critics say the prime minister is trying to deflect attention from a growing outcry over reports his staff flouted Covid rules.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler, Stephen Castle and Megan Specia
item.media:description: Kings Cross train station in London on Dec. 1. The government had already reinstated the mandatory wearing of masks on public transportation in England.

item.title: Angela Merkel’s Political Life in Pictures: The End of an Era
item.description: Images from the former chancellor’s 16 years leading Germany, and from her life before.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy

item.title: Britain Joins U.S. in Diplomatic Boycott of Beijing Olympic Games
item.description: “There will be effectively a diplomatic boycott,” Prime Minister Boris Johnson said of the decision to join the United States and others in registering discontent over human rights abuses in China.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson leaving 10 Downing Street on Wednesday. British athletes will still be allowed to compete at the Games, though no government ministers are expected to attend.

item.title: What Does Russia Want With Ukraine?
item.description: And why people are fearing war there.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in a frontline position.

item.title: Video About Christmas Party Drops Boris Johnson Into Another Mess
item.description: Critics have condemned a recording showing the prime minister’s staff joking about breaches of coronavirus restrictions last year, when Britain was in lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson attending a Christmas event at 10 Downing Street last week.

item.title: It’s a Christmas Sweater on a T. Rex: You Sure You Want to Call It Ugly?
item.description: The Natural History Museum in London outfitted its animatronic Tyrannosaurus rex in a colorful Christmas sweater.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:credit: Trustees of the Natural History Museum, London
item.media:description: The T. rex on display in the Natural History Museum in London took on a decidedly less threatening appearance this week.

item.title: Germany's New Government Vows Tough Approach on China and Russia
item.description: Though its plans are aspirational for the moment, its commitments to Europe, NATO and the trans-Atlantic relationship are solid.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel with President Xi Jinping of China in Beijing in 2019.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A crucial Biden-Putin video call.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Surgeon General Warns of Youth Mental Health Crisis
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic intensified a rise in adolescent depression, anxiety and mental health distress that was underway before the spring of 2020.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.media:description: Mental health issues were rising in the United States even before the pandemic began, with emergency room visits related to depression, anxiety and similar conditions up 28 percent between 2011 and 2015.

item.title: Here are five takeaways from the Biden-Putin call.
item.description: The meeting was a big foreign policy test for President Biden, with consequences for the stability of Europe, the credibility of American threats and the future of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Deputy Secretary of State Victoria S. Nuland told senators that if President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia attacks Ukraine, she expected the Nord Stream 2 pipeline to be suspended.

item.title: Biden and Putin Hold Virtual Summit Over Ukraine
item.description: President Biden said a Russian invasion of Ukraine would result in heavy economic penalties for Mr. Putin, in a tense meeting.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Handout photographs from the White House, top, The Kremlin, bottom
item.media:description: President Biden participated in the virtual summit from the White House Situation Room and the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, joined from his retreat on the Black Sea.

item.title: U.A.E. Changes Its Weekend to Align With West
item.description: The United Arab Emirates, in a nod to global markets, has changed its workweek, declaring that Sunday, a work day in much of the Arab world, is now part of the weekend. Fridays will be half days.
item.dc:creator: Mona El-Naggar
item.media:description: Visitors marking the 50th anniversary of the United Arab Emirates in Dubai last week.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Biden warns Putin on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: The meeting between President Joe Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin came at a high-stakes moment in East-West relations amid rising tension along Russia’s border with Ukraine.

item.title: Marie-Claire Blais, Acclaimed French Canadian Novelist, Dies at 82
item.description: Though largely unknown outside Canada, she was often ranked alongside Margaret Atwood and Alice Munro as one of the country’s greatest living writers.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: A Season in the Life of Emmanuel (Book)
item.media:description: Marie-Claire Blais in 1989. She burst onto the Canadian literary scene in 1959 when she published her first novel, at just 20 years old.

item.title: The pandemic worsened young people’s mental health crisis.
item.description: The message came as part of a rare public advisory from the nation’s top physician, Dr. Vivek H. Murthy.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.media:description: The U.S. surgeon general, Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, at the White House in July.

item.title: French Police Arrest Man in Connection With Khashoggi Killing
item.description: A man with the same name, Khalid Alotaibi, is wanted in connection with the murder of the Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi. A Saudi official says France arrested the wrong man.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Remembering Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi outside the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul after his murder in 2018.

item.title: Skirmishes Break Out Between Ukrainian and Russian Soldiers
item.description: The exchange of fire on the “line of contact” in Ukraine was not unusual, but offered a reminder that, for those on the front line, the grinding war is part of daily life.,
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier patrolling in Avdiivka, a Ukrainian city along the “line of contact” with Russian-backed separatists, on Dec. 2.

item.title: Chile Legalizes Same-Sex Marriage at Fraught Political Moment
item.description: The legalization of same-sex marriage in Chile comes as the country grapples with sweeping demands for social change.
item.dc:creator: Pascale Bonnefoy and Ernesto Londoño
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
Movement for Homosexual Integration and Liberation (Movilh)
item.media:description: A demonstration in Santiago, Chile, in support of same-sex marriage.

item.title: This Robot Looks Like a Pancake and Jumps Like a Maggot
item.description: Researchers designed a soft, legless robot that can hop and navigate obstacle courses.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler

item.title: Biden and Putin Have Very Different Agendas for the Ukraine Call
item.description: Vladimir V. Putin wants Russia to retain sway over western-leaning Ukraine. President Biden aims to secure a more stable and predictable relationship with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in a country neighborhood destroyed by fighting in eastern Ukraine on Dec. 2.

item.title: Ethiopia Says It Recaptured 2 Strategic Towns From Tigray Rebels
item.description: The government said it took back the towns of Dessie and Kombolcha, the latest in a string of wins Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed has claimed in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Members of the Ethiopian National Defense Force transporting an antiaircraft gun in Shewa Robit on Sunday.

item.title: Listen to The Daily: Why does American military assistance to Ukraine matter?
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers with artillery at a base where larger weaponry is stored in Khlibodarivka, Ukraine, in April.

item.title: As fears that Russia may invade Ukraine escalate, Biden spoke with Putin.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden at the White House last week.

item.title: Do Tests Work on the Omicron Variant and Other Questions, Answered
item.description: And experts’ answers.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A vaccination site in Johannesburg.

item.title: Novak Djokovic to Play in Australian Open, Organizers Say
item.description: The announcement came amid speculation about whether Djokovic would travel to Australia because of the vaccination rules. He was also listed as a player in the ATP Cup.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Novak Djokovic of Serbia at the ATP Cup in Melbourne, Australia, in February 2021.

item.title: How Many Countries Will Follow the U.S. Official Snub of Beijing’s Olympics?
item.description: Australia said it would join the diplomatic boycott. Several others have signaled that they would find ways to protest China’s human rights abuses.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Steven Erlanger
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A Winter Olympics countdown display in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: Photos From Indonesia Volcano: Death Toll Rises
item.description: About 17 people were still missing as rescuers searched for survivors buried under volcanic ash.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: With Mount Semeru still spewing ash and smoke in the background on Tuesday, a motorcyclist and his passengers headed elsewhere in Gunung Sawur, Candipuro, Indonesia.

item.title: On the Banks of the Furious Congo River, a 5-Star Emporium of Ambition
item.description: As the clean energy revolution upends the centuries-long lock of fossil fuels on the global economy, dealmakers and hustlers converge on the Fleuve Congo Hotel.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey, Eric Lipton, Michael Forsythe and Ashley Gilbertson
item.category: Fleuve Congo Hotel (Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo)

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Plunge Into Organic Farming Brings Disaster
item.description: The economically troubled country banned chemical fertilizers without preparing farmers, prompting a surge in food prices and worries about shortages.
item.dc:creator: Aanya Wipulasena and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: A vegetable seller at a market in Colombo, Sri Lanka, last month.

item.title: It’s Never Too Late to Go to College and Rewrite Your Story
item.description: Devon Simmons served 15 years in prison for crimes he committed as a teenager. Since then, he’s been on a mission to remake not just his own life, but the legal system itself.
item.dc:creator: Chris Colin
item.category: John Jay College of Criminal Justice
item.media:credit: Nate Palmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Devon Simmons at Columbia University, where he cocreated a program to help the formerly incarcerated.

item.title: Ahead of Biden’s Democracy Summit, China Says: We’re Also a Democracy
item.description: Beijing argues that its system represents a distinctive form of democracy, one that has dealt better than the West with challenges like the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Steven Lee Myers
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Biden and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, at their virtual summit last month, as seen on a Chinese news program on a giant outdoor screen in Beijing.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Early reports on Omicron.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A vaccination site last week in Johannesburg, South Africa.

item.title: Can Olaf Scholz, Germany’s New Chancellor, Revive the Left in Europe?
item.description: Olaf Scholz wants to win back workers who defected to the populist far right. Success could make him a model for Social Democrats everywhere.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Olaf Scholz, center right, with members of the Social Democratic party’s parliamentary group in in Berlin in September. Mr. Scholz will be Germany’s ninth postwar chancellor.

item.title: Michael Steinhardt, Billionaire, Surrenders $70 Million in Stolen Relics
item.description: The hedge fund pioneer is barred for life from buying more antiquities. He turned over 180 stolen objects that had decorated his homes and office.
item.dc:creator: Tom Mashberg
item.media:description: Michael H. Steinhardt in 2006. The district attorney’s office on Monday announced an agreement barring Mr. Steinhardt, a hedge fund billionaire, from ever acquiring antiquities again. He surrendered 180 stolen, trafficked pieces.

item.title: ‘Selling Kabul’ Review: Trapped in a War, and an Apartment
item.description: In Sylvia Khoury’s suspenseful new play, the characters sometimes feel too much like wheels in a machine, but it’s a tense thrill to watch it work.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:description: Dario Ladani Sanchez as Taroon and Marjan Neshat as Afiya in the Sylvia Khoury play “Selling Kabul” at Playwrights Horizons.

item.title: Thinking of hosting a holiday party? Here are a few tips.
item.dc:creator: Ronda Kaysen

item.title: Early Omicron Reports Say Illness May Be Less Severe
item.description: Researchers in South Africa, where the variant is spreading quickly, say it may cause less serious Covid cases than other forms of the virus, but it is unclear whether that will hold true.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel, Richard Pérez-Peña and Emily Anthes
item.media:description: A vaccination site in Johannesburg, South Africa.
